oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Toxic Substances Act: Implications for Veterinary Pharmacology and Therapeutics
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fogleman, R. W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Toxic Substances Act
veterinary pharmacology
drug regulation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: To summarize the implications of ToSCA for veterinarians engaged in veterinary pharmacology as a discipline, it can either be one of the greatest opportunities for personal accomplishment, increased funding for the department, increased graduate training, improving the stature of the veterinary profession and expanding the knowledge of xenobiotic actions, or veterinary pharmacology will represent the flotsam and jetsam left behind by the rapid movements of the tides of change, limited in scope, funds and prestige. The choice is yours. The competition is keen, and the time of opportunity is now - or never. The Toxic Substances Control Act of 1976, or PL 94-469, enacted October 11, 1976, is the culmination of social demands for regulation of chemicals begun in 1896 with the first Pure Foods Act. Subsequently the Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act of 1938 recognized the relationship of dosage to effect as it applied to drugs. This concept of dose-response was extended to pesticides and other chemicals in foods in 1956 and 1962, with the so-called Miller Bill or Section 408, and the Food Additives Amendment, Section 409 of the FD&C Act.
